Andor.description: Andor is the largest, and also the oldest, nation in the Westlands. After the demise of Artur Hawkwing, a line of queens steadily increased Andor's reach from its capital Caemlyn. Andor's flag is a white lion, and the queen wears the Rose Crown on the Lion Throne.

Murandy.description: Murandy is a small nation in the center of the Westlands. Although it is a monarchy in name, its kings and queens have had little influence outside of the capital city Lugard for a very long time.

Illian.description: Illian is the starting point of the famous Hunt for the Horn of Valere. It lies west of Tear, its bitter rival, on the coast of the Sea of Storms. Illian is ruled by a king and the Council of Nine. On the flag, nine golden bees are depicted.

Tear.description: Tear lies east of Illian, its bitter rival. The capital city, also named Tear, is home to the famous, impregnable fortress the Stone of Tear. "Whoever holds the Stone of Tear is Lord of Tear, city and nation." is a well-known saying in Tear. Another interesting feature of Tear is the delta connecting the city to the sea, the Fingers of the Dragon.

Mayene.description: Mayene is ruled by a Lord or Lady called the First of Mayene. Throughout history the Firsts of Mayene have kept the tiny city-state out of the clutches of its neighbour Tear not by having a large army, but through political prowess. On the flag, a hawk is depicted, signifying the rulers' descendance from Artur Hawkwing.

Altara.description: Altara is ruled by a king or a queen from the Throne of the Winds in the capital Ebou Dar. Knive fights are very common in Altara. Another role of knives in Altara are the marriage knives that the women carry, which are not purely decoratory. Gems on the knives indicate whether or not the husband is alive, and how many and of which gender children the woman's children are.

Amadicia.description: Because of the heavy influence of the Children of the Light, channeling and even the presence of Aes Sedai is outlawed in Amadicia. The general suspicion of any channeling-related activities make this country a dangerous place for any village wise woman or other kind of healer.

Ghealdan.description: Ghealdan is a small country between the Mountains of Mist and Garen's wall. Its monarch has the title Defender of Garen's Wall. The country is not rich, most of its money comes from the alum mines in the Mountains of Mist.

Tarabon.description: The tree in Tarabon's flag represents the rumors that Tarabon had pieces of Avendesora in the past. Tarabon is ruled by a Panarch and a monarch, always of opposite sex. The monarchy is passed to children of the current monarch, while the Panarch is chosen by an Assembly of Lords.

Arad Doman.description: Arad Doman is ruled by a king or queen. Contrary to other nations, this title is never passed down to an heir. In Arad Doman, the monarch is chosen by the Council of Merchants. Arad Doman is best known for their female merchants, who wear revealing clothes and use flirtation to get a better deal. Another specialty of Arad Doman are the famed 'razor' horses.

Saldaea.description: When Artur Hawkwing's empire fell, the five northern provinces decided that instead of fighting each other for dominance, they would form stable nations and guard against the blight. Saldaea is the westernmost of these nations, and also the largest. Saldaea is world-renowned for its light cavalry, superior even compared to other borderland nations.

Kandor.description: When Artur Hawkwing's empire fell, the five northern provinces decided that instead of fighting each other for dominance, they would form stable nations and guard against the blight. Kandor is ruled by a monarch, who rules from the Throne of the Clouds.

Arafel.description: When Artur Hawkwing's empire fell, the five northern provinces decided that instead of fighting each other for dominance, they would form stable nations and guard against the blight. People from Arafel often wear bells in their hair, which jingle when they shake their head. They are also severe in their ideas about honour.

Shienar.description: When Artur Hawkwing's empire fell, the five northern provinces decided that instead of fighting each other for dominance, they would form stable nations and guard against the blight. Shienaran warriors shave their hair except for a topknot.

Cairhien.description: Cairhien is most famous for the deeply embedded Daes Dae'mar, the Game of Houses. Cairhienin people are short and reserved, except during he Feast of Lights. For a time, cairhienin traders were welcomed through the waste and prospered trading for silk from faraway Shara, but when king Laman cut down Avendoraldera, this privilege ended in a bloody war.

Malkier.description: Malkier was the northernmost of the original five borderlands. The sign of Malkier was a golden crane. Malkieri men traditionally wore a braided leather cord called a hadori, and married women a red dot on the forehead, a ki'sain as a pledge to raise their children to fight the shadow. The nation lasted for almost a thousand years before it was overrun by shadowspawn and consumed by the blight, as a result of feuds and scheming within the nation.

Garen's Wall.description: Garen's Wall has been an important defensive ridgeline for whichever nation lies south of it, currently the nation of Ghealdan. It is named after general Garen of the now lost nation of Dhowlan.

Mountains of Mist.description: The Mountains of Mist, so named because of their eternally shrouded high peaks, is a huge mountain range separating Tarabon, Arad Doman and the Almoth Plain from Andor and Ghealdan. It is rich in ore, home to a great lake and high waterfall, as well as the origin of several notable rivers.

Damona Mountains.description: The Damona Mountains are relatively young mountains, formed in the Breaking of the World. They are difficult to cross, because many passes turn into a dead end.

Venir Mountains.description: The Venir mountains lie in southern Altara, along the southern coastline.

Black Hills.description: The Black Hills lie between the borderland nations and the Caralain Grass. There are three stedding in the Black Hills.

Banikhan Mountains.description: Also known as The Seawall, the Banikhan Mountains are located in Saldaea, close to World's End. Saldaea's famous ice peppers grow no the mountainsides and there are mines rich with gemstones.

World's End.description: World's End is a rocky, mountainous region just south of the Great Blight. Its biggest feature is the large peninsula into the Aryth Ocean.

Nemarellin Mountains.description: The Nemarellin Mountains lie on the western coast of Illian. In Illian, they are also called the West Wall of the Country.

Chishen Mountains.description: The CHishen Mountains are located in southeastern Andor, near the river Erinin.

Haddon Mirk.description: Haddon Mirk is a vast area with swamps, marshland and some forests. Because of this unhospitable geography, not many people live here. For the same reason however, it is very suited for anyone looking to disappear.

Drowned Lands.description: The Drowned Lands north of Mayene, together with the Termool, form another natural barrier to the Aiel Waste. They are also home to a number of exotic animals like brightly colored birds and swamp cats.

Bay of Remara.description: The Bay of Ramara is a large bay separating the country of Tear from the city-state Mayene.

Cindaking.description: Cindaking is a Sea Folk island in the Sea of Storms south of Godan and Mayene, near the Bay of Remara.

Kabal Deep.description: The Kabal Deep is a large bay between Illian and Altara. It is known for heavy storms in the winter.

Dead Sea.description: The Dead Sea is a part of the Aryth Ocean north of where the Mountains of Dhoom lower into the sea. It is possible but unconfirmed that the blight continues into this stretch of the ocean, explaining the name Dead Sea.

Aile Dashar.description: Aile Dashar is a Sea Folk-controlled archipelago in the Aryth Ocean.

The Great Blight.description: The Great Blight is a huge corrupted area north of the Mountains of Dhoom. The cause of this corruption is the influence of the Dark One extending from Shayol Ghul.

Shayol Ghul.description: This used to be a tropical island and popular vacation spot. Now it is the place where the Dark One's power is greatest. Within this huge, dark mountain is the Pit of Doom. Below the mountain lies Thakan'dar, where shadow-forgers craft the myrddraal blades requiring human sacrifice.

Thakan'dar.description: In the valley of Thakan'dar below the slopes of Shayol Ghul the shadow-forgers forge the feared blades of the Myrddraal, which require human sacrifices.

The Blasted Lands.description: The Blasted Lands are a part of what is now the Great Blight where the fighting of the War of Power was heaviest. Thakan'Dar and Shayol Ghul lie in the blasted lands, further increasing the lifelessness of this area becasue of the influence of the Dark One.

Lake Somal.description: Lake Somal is the biggest lake in the Westlands. It lies by the Mountains of Mist east of the Paerish Swar on Almoth Plain.

Paerish Swar.description: Paerish Swar, also known as the Darkwood, is a large forest on Almoth Plain next to Lake Somal.

Almoth Plain.description: Almoth Plain separates the nations of Arad Doman to the north and Tarabon to the south. These two nations have a long history of warring over the region, which is not part of any country. The largest city of Almoth Plain is Falme, located on Toman Head.

Toman Head.description: Toman Heaf is a peninsula on Almoth Plain into the Aryth Ocean. The largest and only notable city on Toman Head is Falme.

Windbiter's Finger.description: Windbiter's Finger is a peninsula separating the Aryth Ocean an the Sea of Storms. It is very jagged and partly submerged, making it very treacherous for ships passing by it.

Cordese Hills.description: The Cordese Hills are a group of hills north and north-west of Ebou Dar.

Sea of Storms.description: The Sea of Storms is a large ocean south of the Westlands and north of the Land of Madmen. The only people to sail the Sea of Storms are the seafolk, who trade with the major ports on this ocean.

Forest of Shadows.description: The Forest of SHadows is also known as the Great Blackwood. It separates the Two Rivers from the nation of Ghealdan. Together with the White River, the Forest of Shadows makes the Two Rivers as good as isolated from the south.

Hills of Absher.description: The Hills of Absher are located between Baerlon and Whitebridge in Andor. They are mostly deserted, except for the Caemlyn Road which passes through them for a while.

Dhallin Forest.description: Dhallin forest is a forest in Ghealdan.

Doirlon Hills.description: The Doirlon Hills are located near the eastern border of Illian, next to the Plains of Maredo. Their location makes them an important defensive feature for the nation.

Cumbar Hills.description: The Cumbar Hills are located in Murandy.

Splintered Hills.description: The Splintered Hills are located in Andor.

Caralain Grass.description: The Caralain Grass is a great area of plains located centrally in the Westlands. The great conqueror Artur Hawkwing planned to build his capital here, but he died before the plan could be realized. The name 'Caralain' comes from the kingdom of Caralain, which claimed the plains after the War of the Hundred Years but faded into obscurity the next few centuries.

Braem Wood.description: Braem Wood is a vast area of woodland in northern Andor. Its name comes from the ancient ogier-built city of Braem, which belonged to the nation of Coremanda.

Tunaighan Hills.description: The Tunaighan Hills lie in Andor close to Caemlyn.

Hills of Kintara.description: The Hills of Kintara are named after a now-extinct nation. They are located just north of the city of Far Madding.

Molvaine Gap.description: The Molvaine Gap is a passage through the Damona Mountains.

Plains of Maredo.description: The Plains of Maredo are vast plains between the nations of Illian, Tear and Andor.

Fingers of the Dragon.description: The Fingers of the Dragon are the delta formed by the river Erinin into the Sea of Storms. The city of Tear is located just north of the Fingers. The curves and narrowness of the waters make approaching the city difficult and a guide from Tear is required by law for every ship, although the Sea Folk can find their own way and tend to ignore their guides.

The Termool.description: The Termool is a desert south of the Waste separating it from the Sea of Storms. The desert is so devoid of water that even Aiel cannot cross it. On top of this, there is a constant threat of sudden windstorms which can last for days.

The Silk Road.description: The Silk Road is a road through the Aiel Waste connecting the kingdom of Cairhien with remote and secluded Shara, bringing a new trade option for rare goods previously only available through the Sea Folk. Especially the rare silk from which the road gets its name brought traders from Cairhien great riches.

The Great Rift.description: The Great Rift is an enormous canyon separating the Aiel Waste and Shara. Beyond the Rift huge mountains make entering Shara this way even more difficult.

Shara.description: Shara is a huge nation east of the Aiel Waste. Contact with outsiders is heavily prohibited, so not much is known about the people and the culture.

The Cliffs of Dawn.description: The Cliffs of Dawn are high cliffs along the northeastern Waste, separating it from Shara. THere are only six scalable spots on the cliffs, and at each there is a Sharan trade town.

The Spine of the World.description: The Spine of the World is a huge mountain range separating the Westlands from the Aiel Waste. It ranges from the Mountains of Dhoom in the north to the Bay of Remara in the south and is home to several stedding.
The Spine of the World.imageCredit: Mike S. Miller, Etienne St Laurent

Maraside Mountains.description: The Maraside Mountains are an extension of the Spine of the World running almost the the village of Maerone, on the river Erinin.

Kinslayer's Dagger.description: Kinslayer's Dagger is an extension of the Spine of the World. The origin of the name is the Dragon Lews Therin Telamon, also known as the kinslayer after he killed his family because of the Dark One's taint on Saidin.

Jangai Pass.description: The Jangai Pass is the largest pass through the Spine of the World. The Silk Road goes through this pass, connecting Cairhien to far-away Shara.

Niamh Passes.description: The Niamh Passes is a group of narrow paths connecting Shienar to the Aiel Waste. The Aiel sometimes raid Shienar through these passes. To defend from the raids the Shienarans have built a fortress named Ankor Dail near the passes.

Tarwin's Gap.description: Tarwin's Gap is a pass between the Mountains of Dhoom and the Spine of the World. It is the easiest way to enter the blight, but also for shadowspawn from the blight to enter the Westlands.

The Aiel Waste.description: The Aiel Waste is the home of the Aiel, who call it the Three-fold Land. The name refers to what the waste gives them: a shaping stone to make them, a testing ground to prove their worth, and a punishment for their sin. It is so barren and desolate that only the Aiel can survive in the Waste for extended periods. Even trollocs fear to enter the waste, calling it The Dying Ground.

Mountains of Dhoom.description: The Mountains of Dhoom run along the edge of the Blight across the entire world, north of the Westlands, the Waste, Shara and even on the other side of the ocean in distant Seanchan. The mountains were formed during the Breaking of the World.

Plain of Lances.description: The Plain of Lances is a plain on the border of Kandor and Saldaea. Its name probably originates from the two countries' military exercises on the plains.

Tremalking.description: Tremalking is the largest of the Sea Folk islands. It is mainly inhabited by the peaceful Amayar.

Qaim.description: Qaim is one of the Sea Folk islands.

Aile Somera.description: Aile Somera is an archipelago ruled by the Sea Folk.

Aile Jafar.description: Aile Jafar is an archipelago ruled by the Sea Folk.
